Posts.Title: I need some feedback on chemo meds Piffken joanneasiata

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2009 01:11PM LittleRed wrote: Dear Piffken: I think I remember hearing that the Taxotere is more likely to result in nail loss.  You may want to follow up on that.  There was talk here on one thread about the use of black nail polish to help prevent damage/loss and/or the use of cold packs on hands and feet.  I have no idea whether these help or not.  Be good to you -
Posts.Title: I need some feedback on chemo meds Piffken joanneasiata

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2009 09:41AM LittleRed wrote: Dear Piffken: You will get the three drugs I did.  I had 8 treatments over 16 weeks.  The schedule was condensed (every 2 weeks vs. my oncs standard of every 3 weeks) because I was considered young (44 ha, ha, ha) and strong and able to do a more rigorous schedule. First 4 were Cytoxan&Adriamycin followed by 4 Taxol. Nausea with the C/A was greater, though I never got sick.  (I included a ginger supplement every day, and 3 days before chemo I doubled the dose through the 2nd day after chemo.  Not sure if it helped, but it didn't hurt.  Studies have shown it helps many with nausea.)  I was tired, but able to work PT.  Taxol was more tiring, but didn't make me as nauseous.  With Taxol I had to pre-med with steroids - that made me really edgy...They also started each Taxol with a Benadryl dose - that made me REALLY tired. I lost my hair pretty much after the 3rd treatment.  My nails were fantastic until the 2nd to last treatment.  I've been out 6 weeks now, and those that died during treatment are falling off now.  Not painful, but uncomfortable.  I cover them with waterproof band aids when I go out - those hardly ever wear off. (My onc said she rarely sees nail loss with Taxol, but it can happen.  Guess I'm the lucky winner in that crappy pool!) I have a little numbness (neuropathy)  in my fingers, but my feet remain very numb.  The numbness started somewhere around my 6th treatment.  I take a B complex supplement that's supposed to help for that.  The numbness in my fingers comes nd gos, but I haven't felt a significant change in my feet yet. I agree:  stay hydrated as best you can.  Chemo can do serious damage to your mouth.  My dentist prescribed a Rx fluoride toothpaste, and Biotene brand mouth wash and Biotene dry mouth moisturizer (Biotene is sold over-the-counter).  I got the dry mouth during the C/A, but it was kept under control with these products - I never got mouth sores. Taxol wasn't so bad for dry mouth.  I also had to pre-medicate before visiting the dentist (antibiotics) so check with your onc, even for a cleaning. I lost my taste for things.  Many foods I commonly ate before tasted metallic or even rancid.  That quickly changed a few weeks after finishing chemo.  (I'm one of the few who lost weight during chemo.  Losing my taste buds was not a help.) Hot flashes became routine during the end of chemo.  They continue now that I'm on Tamoxifen.  I hope they will diminish over time.  They contribute to sleeplessness, which hit me during the Taxol.  No problems sleeping during C/A. The neulasta (sp?) shot which you get the next day can make people sick.  I only experienced pain at the injection site for a few days. The toughest thing for me however, was the emotional.  If you've got the emotional support you need that will make it MUCH easier.  And don't be concerned about asking for help.  Now is the time to respect your needs. I hope this doesn't scare you.  Everyone is so different, so no two experiences will be alike.  Not everything hits you at once either.  But you need to know YOU WILL get through the chemo:  The view is better on the other side.  We'll all be rooting for you here! Take good care of you!!

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 10:44AM LittleRed wrote: goldie0827: Not sure if you've tried this, but I used to flat iron my VERY curly long hair. However, if I didn't use a serum, it took way too long and I had to go over the same hair too many times risking damage.  I liked Paul Mitchell's product.  I would clip up my completely dry hair and work from the back forward and up.  Put a dime sized drop of the product in my hands, rub together, then work through the hair.  Then straighten small sections at a time, running a comb through behind the flat iron to make sure it stayed straight and started to cool asap.  Repeat serum and flat iron with each section. I hope this helps -

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2009 09:26AM LittleRed wrote: Dear chinablue: My hair did not.  My eyelashes and eyebrows went shortly after I finished my last Taxol, as did my fingernails which were incredible up until my 2nd Taxol treatment.  I'm still waiting for them to grow out.  They've been turning black and breaking off.  (From what I understand this is not a common SE from Taxol - usually happens with the sister drug Taxotere - I just got 'lucky'.)  My lashes and brows are coming in fine now, and hair is progressing. (My avitar pic is from Friday.) I think some have had hair start to grow back while on Taxol, so don't be discourged.  I may be in the minority, I don't know.  The other posters here should be able to share their experience.  Best of luck! Be good to you -

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2009 03:28PM LittleRed wrote: I just updated my profile with a pic - 6 weeks out of chemo.  (I started taking pics at 4 weeks - I figure when I'm unhappy about the hair thing I can go back and "remember when" so I don't feel so bad!) I have fuzz all over and the hair is coming in too.  I don't let many people see my head at this stage of the game, but you ladies are different.  You understand.  I am so happy just to have a hairline, even if it is mostly fuzz...well, I'm going to refer to it as a hairline anyway... My eyelashes are coming in, but I have not used any product on them.  The lower ones are pretty short, maybe a 5th of their normal length and pretty evenly spaced across; the uppers are also short, but more patchy.  (chelev:  I only have one old eyelash left now - the other fell out when I ran to the store for that brow pencil. You warned me. lol!) My eyebrow hair just started to appear at the end of this week.  I have very little left to speak of, but the new growth is now visible closest to my nose and working  its way out.  They kinda sprouted overnight. Nose hair is coming back; the facial hair is starting to come in.  Leg hair unfortunately showed up by weeks 4/5  so I really DO have to shave now.  And yes, regrettably, I now know I'm going to have to deal with my bikini line once more,  but at least not for a while. I've been taking my mutlivitamin and eating protein and good veggies where possible.  No special supplements or topical treatments for me at this point, except the B complex I take for neuropathy - that does contain some biotin. I would worry about the Latisse risk for discoloration too, but my friend just started using the lash renewal stuff from the drug store.  I have to check back with her to see how that's going.  I might give it a try if she thinks it's helped her.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 10:14AM LittleRed wrote: Day: I am so sorry you are going through all this.  I know it is hard not to be discouraged. You can do the chemo and rads and get through it.   Go to the chemo threads.  You are not alone going through this and there are lots of us who did it who will tell you we are glad we did and you can too! I'm not as familiar with all the recon issues and complications that come up, but there is the Exchange City thread here that is visited by a number of extremely knowledgeable women.  Whippetmom is a wonderful woman who I am sure would provide feedback for you if you reach out to her.  A number of women have discussed disappointing results with recon surgery, but it has been corrected and they are now very pleased.  I'm sure you can find the support you need there. Kathy16:  The original plan was to do all my recon at the same time as my mx:  R-LAT flap with implant and L-aug for symmetry.  However, I was informed that if the initial surgical biopsy of nodes was positive, they would to the L-aug and only the R-mx and put in a R-TE.  This is because nodes meant radiation post-chemo.  They thought it would be better not to put the newly moved muscle/tissue/skin under the stress of rads and they didn't want to delay rads. So I am now done with chemo and rads.  My PS wants to wait until May to do my exchange - 3 months after that, fipple, rest, then tattoo.  So, this time next year I could actually be done.  (?)Sometimes that gets me really down - waiting so long for all that, not to mention some hair (mine used to be pretty long, so that's even further out).  But if I can enjoy the next 30 years healthy and feeling whole again.  It will be worth it all.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 12:58PM LittleRed wrote: Dear strngwmn39: I had my mx in late April, so I've had a while to gain back my strength and flexibility.  My surgeon said to do my exercises, and when I thought I couldn't go any further, to go another inch.  It was painful at first but I am greatly improved at this point.  I still have pain when I extend fully over my head, but even that has reduced.  I finished chemo 3 weeks ago and start radiation on Monday 9/28.  I think you are correct, the field of treatment will be larger that it might be for lumpectomy, but I don't know if that will mean different SEs or not.  You might want to ask your onc about taking something for the discomfort prior to your treatments - Tylenol or whatever.  The treatment sessions are not that long, but you could ask about pre-medicating to see if that makes you more comfortable.  Best of luck - take care of yourself.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 03:21PM LittleRed wrote: PauldingMom: I had a left mx on April 29, finished 4AC/4Taxol chemo on September 4, and I'm starting radiation on September 28 for 6.5 weeks.  I have been in for my CAT, measures, and tattoos.  Apart from having to remain completely still for about 15-20 minutes, and the slight pinch from the tattoos, it was fine.  I was told they would give me the creams I needed to use, but that I should use unscented Tom's of Maine for deodorant, and a simple mild non-scented soap like Dove for sensitive skin. Everyone has told me to apply the creams as liberally as possible, and one of my breast buddies suggested I buy nursing pads so I don't soil my bras or my clothes.  (Guess she swam in the stuff, but it worked for her.) I'm trying to decide if I should do AM or PM treatment also.  I want to go back to work and I'm not sure what would be best.  I'm leaning toward PM so I can go to bed early and be rested for a long commute and work, but I will still have a long commute to get to afternoon treatment, and then head home (about 20 mins) to help my son with homework, sports practice, and make dinner.  Not sure I which way to go.  They have a brand new machine where I am, so I do not anticipate delays from that. P.S.  I was thinking of putting my wig on backwards and being Cousin It for Halloween...

Has anybody already started rads and work?  How's it going?  I feel stronger now that I'm done with chemo, but I'm concerned about my stamina with the rads. Thanks -

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 04:46PM LittleRed wrote: 9 treatments so far.  I'm not getting nausea, but have some breast pain, and anxiety and depression are creeping back up again.  What's that about?  I returned to work (3 days) PT and I'm exhausted by the time I leave for rads in the early afternoon.  I know the return to work - which I wanted - is stressful.  The commute is stressful.  The new treatment process is stressful.  Started the Tamoxafen.  Hot flashes keep me up all night and bug me all day.  The treatment may be "going OK", bit I feel like I'm slipping backwards emotionally and I'm so tired...yikes!
Posts.Title: October Rads. 2009 PauldingMom linn56

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 05:05PM LittleRed wrote: Dear sopris: You are more than halfway there!  Hang in there. Be good to you -
Posts.Title: October Rads. 2009 PauldingMom linn56

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 07:49AM LittleRed wrote: Blondie: I am so sorry you are feeling scared.  This is scary business.  All I can say is you are not alone in your concerns.  We are hear for you.  Did you do chemo, or did they say only rads? Ask your rad onc for some Auquafor mixed with Lidocane.  It will allow you to keep your skin moisturized, but it won't sting when you apply it and it will ever so slightly numb the areas that are sore. Be good to you -
Posts.Title: October Rads. 2009 PauldingMom linn56

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 09:15PM LittleRed wrote: Dear vnelson: I have been advised to leave my port in until my next mamo in March.  I did have node involvement, so my onc wanted to leave it in for 5-6 months post chemo.  I'm not happy about waiting, but I'll just have to get used to it...
Posts.Title: October Rads. 2009 PauldingMom linn56

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 05:54PM LittleRed wrote: Sakura73:  YEAH!!!  My last day of rads is tomorrow! Everyone:  Hang in there.  You can do it!! Sending you all good thoughts of healing, peace, and comfort! Be good to you -
Posts.Title: October Rads. 2009 PauldingMom linn56

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 11:23PM LittleRed wrote: Thank you ladies.  Yes, it IS a good feeling to be done with the rads.  I brought in goodies for my rad techs and nurses to say thanks for all their care and then went next door to the infusion center to have my port flushed - had to bring those girls something good too!! I'm so glad to be done with chemo, and so glad rads is finished, but I will miss seeing all the wonderful women and men who have been there to care for me - day after day, week after week, month after month - and help me through the treatments, the SEs, the emotional pain...they have made me laugh, hugged me when I cried, and help me keep the faith! Just want to give a shout out to all the nurses, doctors, techs, and staff at our medical centers that do such good work taking care of us!!  I am so very grateful for those that put so much heart and soul into their work! PauldingMom you are nearly there - Yeah!!  (ME DONE NOW!!) Suzanne3131:  It is easy to forget...I have to remind myself too...but they're words to for us all to LIVE by... Be good to you -
